docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing 300 nurses' aides, housekeepers and other nonprofessional workers at Lawrence Hospital reached a tentative five-year contract yesterday and called off a strike planned for today. Officials with the union, 1199/SEIU, said the deal, the first union contract reached at the hospital, would provide annual raises of 3 percent for the first four years and a wage reopener in the fifth year. Lawrence Hospital also agreed to join the union's benefits fund, meaning that many workers, whose pay averages $20,000 to $30,000 a year, would no longer have to contribute $1,200 to $1,900 a year toward their benefits. The hospital had resisted unionization for 37 years before 1199/SEIU unionized it last year. A ratification vote is set for this week. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronxville: Hospital Strike Avoided

docs.abstract: Service Employees International Union reaches contract with Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, NY, covering nurses' aides, housekeepers and nonprofessional workers; workers will receive 3 percent wage increase each year for five years and coverage by union's health benefit plan (S)

byline.original: By Steven Greenhouse (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the morning of March 19, Dr. Kenneth I. Berns, chief executive of Mount Sinai Medical Center, was preparing for a meeting with union officials when he received a visit from the chairman of the board, Peter W. May. The two men -- the respected medical academic and the corporate turnaround artist famed for resuscitating the Snapple beverage brand -- had been brought in a year before to lead the rescue of Mount Sinai, one of a handful of elite teaching hospitals in New York City. Not only was it bleeding tens of millions of dollars a year, but the death of a liver donor in its heralded transplant program had dealt Mount Sinai's reputation a stinging blow.

headline.main: How a Venerable Hospital Helped Undermine Its Own Health

docs.abstract: Profile of Mount Sinai Medical Center, venerable New York City teaching hospital, chronicling its descent into dire financial straits and turmoil; Mount Sinai's leaders tend to depict their hospital largely as victim, overwhelmed by dwindling flow of government money, ever-more-costly obligations to the poor and other external forces that have reshaped American health care; while that is one side of story, Mount Sinai has also been constant colaborator in its own decline, having allowed culture of fiscal laxity and excess to thrive through years of generous Medicare and Medicaid payments; number of trustees and physicians say resignation of Kenneth I Berns as chief executive shows determination of Peter W May, chairman of board, to seize control after years of drift; many people speak highly of Dr Kenneth L Davis, new chief executive; photos; chart illustrates budget problems at Mount Sinai (L)
docs.snippet: On the morning of March 19, Dr. Kenneth I. Berns, chief executive of Mount Sinai Medical Center, was preparing for a meeting with union officials when he received a visit from the chairman of the board, Peter W. May.     The two men -- the respected...

docs.lead_paragraph: In his 17 days of molding tool boxes, Wang Chenghua learned to work like a metronome. He slipped strips of metal under a mechanical hammer with his right hand, then swept molded parts into a pile with his left. He did this once a second for a 10-hour shift, minus a half-hour lunch. Just before lunch on the 18th day, he lost the beat. The hammer, backed by 4,000 pounds of pressure, ripped through the middle and ring fingers of his right hand, reducing them to pulp.

headline.main: China's Workers Risk Limbs in Export Drive

docs.abstract: Yongkang, China, has 7,000 metal-working factories--all privately owned--that make many items with metallic innards; these goods are exported around world; many of rudimentary machines in Yongkang's factories lack screens or other safety devices; result is that Yongkang is dismemberment capital of country; at least once every day someone is rushed from one of factories to one of dozen clinics that specialize in treating hand, arm and finger injuries; unofficial estimates run as high as 2,500 such accidents each year; lawyers, journalists and doctors say hundreds or thousands of injured workers are left out of official count because boss does not have insurance, or because workers were not hired legally, or because city officials are under perssure to show that they have safety under control; reality, all over China, is that workplace casualties have become endemic; 140,000 people died in work-related accidents in China last year; steps government has taken to address issue have done little to solve fundamental problems; high rates of injury and death are being tolerated in China as price of economic progress; photos; chart; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS soon as Dr. Patricia Meyer examined the patient who walked into her office, she suspected he had cancer. The man had inflamed lymph nodes and Dr. Meyer wanted to order a number of tests, including a CAT scan of the man's lungs. But such diagnostic procedures are expensive and, like many of the patients who walk into the Open Door Family Health Center here, the man had no health insurance. Thus began the scramble that is all too familiar for medical professionals trying to care for those without insurance. ''It's really rough, and you have to be fairly creative to advocate for your patients,'' said Dr. Meyer, a family practitioner and staff physician at
docs.abstract: Article on plight of people lacking health insurance who, because of inability to pay for tests, must wait until medical problems reach crisis stage to be treated in emergency rooms under emergency Medicaid; health experts estimate that 17 or 18 percent of Westchester County residents, 80 percent of working poor, are uninsured; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PEGGY YARROW wants a driver's license desperately. A single mother, Ms. Yarrow, a Peruvian citizen who has been in the United State for about 10 years, needs it to get to supermarkets for groceries and diapers, to send her daughter, Shaynna Saenz, 2, to preschool, to visit the pediatrician and to find a job to supplement her $600 a month welfare income. But when Ms. Yarrow, who is a permanent resident of the United States, applied for a license late last year at the Stamford office of the Department of Motor Vehicles, she was told she wasn't eligible because she wasn't a citizen. ''How else am I supposed to live?'' she asked. ''You cannot live your life here without driving.''

headline.main: A Nervous State Looks to Limit Licenses

docs.abstract: Article on tougher stance being taken in Connecticut and other states since September 2001 terrorist attacks over issuing driver's licenses to noncitizens; Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles and number of state lawmakers have introduced bills to restrict immigrants' access to driver's licenses; immigration lawyers and Connecticut Attorney Gen Richard Blumenthal oppose measures as unconstitutional; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The griping about how much or how little Princeton University pays in fees and taxes doesn't normally begin until, say, October in a typical election year. But this year there may be a Democratic primary for mayor of Princeton Borough, and in a one-party town like this, that means the next mayor will be all but elected in June. So the campaign, and therefore the griping, has started early and politely. Joseph P. O'Neill, a retired Georgetown University professor and borough councilman, who is running for mayor, has drawn up an analysis of what top universities of Princeton's rank voluntarily pay.

headline.main: Princeton Journal; This Town vs. Gown Fight Is All About Taxes

docs.abstract: Joseph P O'Neill, who is running for mayor of Princeton, NJ, is trying to bring some clarity to perennial tussle over what Princeton University should be paying in taxes; school is already biggest taxpayer in borough; university spokesperson Pam Hersh wonders if borough's large budget could be trimmed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Stephen C. Albrecht of Olympia, Wash., called a hospital in Tacoma recently to inquire about one of his patients, an 18-year-old treated for an infectious disease, he had trouble getting information. Under a new policy at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington, a 558-bed nursing home in Rockville, Md., callers can get information about patients only if they have a password or ''verification code.''

headline.main: Health System Warily Prepares for New Privacy Rules

docs.abstract: New federal rules on privacy of medical records will take effect on April 14, and they have already touched off quiet revolution in health care industry; whole industry of consultants is advising health care providers on how to comply; federal officials say new rules should not interfere with flow of information needed to treat patients and pay claims, but doctors and hospitals, uncertain about what the rules allow, have become much more cautious about sharing or disclosing information; researchers, journalists and clergy members say hospitals are refusing to provide certain types of information that has been routinely available for many years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BACK in his day, former Mayor Edward I. Koch used to stroll the streets of New York City asking ''How'm I doing?'' It was one way of evaluating his administration, but it gave only a partial picture of what was really going on in his city. It is the same with other measures. Analysts like to quote straightforward numbers like the gross domestic product or the Dow Jones industrial average when they talk about progress. But while such indicators say much about the overall health of the economy, they say little about daily life in a city like New York or about the people like Memon Ahmed who live here.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the stock market was roaring, many investors scoffed at variable annuities, the insurance industry's version of mutual funds. Because variable annuities added insurance protection to mutual funds, they carried higher fees than pure mutual funds did and, in most cases, the insurance features were not being used.

headline.main: Mutual Funds Report; Annuity Death Benefit Starts Paying Its Way

docs.abstract: Death benefit feature of variable annuities, which seemed superfluous to many critics during bull market, is proving valuable since market plunge; guarantees investor's estate will get full amount of initial investment should investor die with loss; graph of annuity assets; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I would like to reply to the reader who wrote a letter [March 30] in response to the article ''Using Solar Power With LIPA's Aid'' [March 16] that questioned the merits of a solar system I just installed on my home. First of all, solar photovoltaic systems are completely maintenance-free, with no moving parts to replace or repair. Once the system is installed, no further costs are incurred.

headline.main: Finding Real Benefits In Solar Power

docs.abstract: Long Island Shines Solar Outreach and Education Program manager Kathleen A Whitley letter on March 30 letter holds solar photovoltaic systems are maintenance-free, cost-effective and provide insurance against rising electric rates
